metadata.title: Cellulose Nanocrystals as Anti-Oil Nanomaterials for Separating Crude Oil from Aqueous Emulsions and Mixtures

Email: jing_yang@zju.edu.cn; xuzk@zju.edu.cn. † The authors contribute equally to the work. Electronic Supplementary Information (ESI) available: Wetting ability tests and morphology characterization of superhydrophilic nanomaterials and CNCs-based nanopapers and nanocoatings on various substrates; separation performance of CNCs-based nanopapers; schematic diagram of the homemade separation device; videos recording crude oil-fouled CNCs-based nanopapers, PES membrane with PDDA/PSS nanocoating, Cu foil and Si wafer with CNCs-based coatings being immersed into hot water. See DOI: 10.1039/x0xx00000x
Received 00th January 20xx, Accepted 00th January 20xx
DOI: 10.1039/x0xx00000x
www.rsc.org/
Cellulose Nanocrystals as Anti-Oil Nanomaterials for Separating Crude Oil from Aqueous Emulsions and Mixtures Ming-Bang Wu†a, Chao Zhang†a, Jun-Ke Pia, Chang Liua, Jing Yang*a and Zhi-Kang Xua
There is an increasing demand for anti-oil materials applicable in the efficient separation of crude oil from oil-in-water emulsions and oil/water mixtures for oilywater treatment and oil spill remediation. Most of the reported superhydrophilic materials are able to repel model oils, but still easy to be adsorbed and fouled by crude oil with high viscosity and strong adhesive property. Herein, we report cellulose nanocrystals (CNCs) for fabricating nanopapers and nanocoatings with high anti-crude oil characteristics. These CNCs are composed of cellulose chains densely and rigidly arranged in the crystalline state, which rigorously restricts the motions of the hydrophilic groups on the material surfaces. They show more stable water binding affinity and lower underwater adhesive force than other super-hydrophilic materials. Therefore, the nanopapers and nano-coatings are available to eliminate oil contamination from their surfaces not only in the water-wetted state, but also in the dry state. The nanopapers fabricated by vacuum-filtration can effectively separate surfactant-stabilized crude oil-in-water emulsions. Those meshes assemled with nanocoatings are useful for the separation of crude oil/water mixtures with extremely high water flux up to 35,000 L m-2 h-1. Meanwhile, the CNCsbased nanomaterials show excellent anti-crude oil property, no water flux decline, good pH stability and high salt resistance. All these characteristics makes them potentially applicable to the remediation of crude oil spills on offshore seawater.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Crude oil spill accidents have taken place frequently and caused not only severe damage to marine ecosystem, but also
big threat to human health.1-2 Therefore, various materials have been studied to address the growing concern of separating these spilled oils from a large quantity of oilywater.3-7 Much attention has been paid to those superhydrophobic/superoleophilic or superhydrophilic/underwatersuperoleophobic materials in the form of membranes,8-10 meshes,11-12 sponges13-14 and textils.15-17 Actually, the hydrophobic materials possess lower surface energy than the hydrophilic ones, which resuting in that the hydrophobic materials are much easier to be poluted by oil than the hydrophilic ones. It is well accepted that those superhydrophilic/underwater-superoleophobic materials have excellent oil-repellent property for light oil.18-20 However, they are easily and severely polluted during the separation of crude oil/water mixtures because of the high viscosity and adhesive property of crude oil.
To address this issue, some underwater oil-repellent materials have been recently reported for crude oil/water separation.21-31 In general, these materials, including polymeric hydrogels,21-24 zwitterionic polyelectrolytes25-27 and inorganic minerals,28-31 have more exceptional binding affinity with water than with crude oil when they are in a water-wetted state. However, in their dry state, these underwater oilrepellent materials are very easy to adsorb crude oil with low surface tension and high adhesive property. In this case, the oil-adsorbed surfaces are difficult to be recovered and thus these materials should be pre-wetted by water before the practical crude oil/water separation. Furthermore, the excellent oil-repellent property usually originates from the outward hydrophilic groups on the material surfaces. When they are exposed to non-polar media (e.g., air), the hydrophilic groups will spontaneously orient inward to minimize the overall surface energy of the materials.32-33 This conversion would lead to severe deterioration of the surface hydrophilicity, which significantly restricts their practical application in oil/water separation. To the best of our knowledge, only very few materials like poly(2-methacryl-oyloxylethyl phosphorylcholine)25 and cellulose nanofibrils (CNFs)34 are capable of keeping the origin orientation of the hydrophilic

sections.text:
2 | J. Name., 2012, 00, 1-3 This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
Scheme 1. Schematic illustration of a) CNCs, b) CNCs nanopaper and c) CNCs nanocoating fabrication process.
groups when exposed to oil or air so that they can remain their surface hydrophilicity even in the dry state. From their chemical structure, One can find that both of them possess abundant hydrophilic groups which are closely and densely bonded to the material surfaces. Therefore, the orientation transformation is confined for the hydrophilic groups when the materials are exposed to different surroundings.25,34
Herein, we report cellulose nanocrystals (CNCs) as the oilrepellent materials for the first time in fabricating nanopapers and nanocoatings (Scheme 1(a)) to separate crude oil from the oil-in-water emulsions and oil/water mixtures. The CNCs were fabricatd by sulfuric acid hydrolysis of microcrystalline cellulose (MCC). Compared with CNFs produced by the TEMPO-oxidation method reported in previous anti-oil work34, the preparation process of CNCs is simpler and more economical. Note that the CNCs have abundant sulfuric acid ester groups, which show stronger hydratability than most of other hydrophilic groups like carboxyl and hydroxyl groups.35-37 Moreover, the cellulose chains are densely and rigidly arranged in the crystalline state of CNCs, which rigorously restricts the motions of the hydrophilic groups. They are thus difficult in reorientation when exposed the CNCs-based materials to air or even to oil. These characteristics combined endow the CNCs with stable hydrophilicity and ultimately superior oil-repellent capability over other known superhydrophilic materials. In this work, we facilely fabricated CNCs nanopapers on microfiltration membranes by vacuumfiltration method and CNCs nanocoatings on a series of substrates, including meshes, silica wafers, glass plates, and plastic sheets via layer-by-layer (LBL) assembly method (Scheme 1(b-c)). Both the nanopaper and the nanocoating show underwater oil contact angles above 150° and ultralow crude oil adhesive forces. In particular, the CNCs nanopapers with small pores can effectively separate surfactant-stabilized crude oil-in-water emulsions, which are hardly achieved in previous reports.22 The meshes with CNCs nanocoatings were further applied for the separation of crude oil/water mixture
with extremely high water flux up to 35,000 L m-2 h-1. Our CNCs-based nanomaterials show excellent anti-crude oil property, no water flux decline (even after 12 cycles), good pH stability and high salt resistance, which makes them potentially applicable to the remediation of crude oil spills on offshore seawater.

sections.heading: 2. Results and discussion
sections.text:
CNCs were exfoliated from MCC by a hydrolysis process with aqueous solution of sulfuric acid.38-39 This hydrolysis process endows the cellulose nanomaterials with abundant sulfuric acid ester groups on their outer surfaces. The FT-IR spectra of CNCs display typical absorption peaks at 1250 and 1350 cm-1 due to the S=O stretching vibration (Figure 1(a)), and the XPS analyses also confirm the introduction of sulfuric acid ester groups by the hydrolysis process (Table S1 in SI). Conductometric titration was further used to quantify the sulfuric acid ester group content, which reaches up to 3×10-3 mmol m-2 (Figure 1(b)). These abundant sulfuric acid ester groups will enable the CNCs-based nanomaterials to be with outstanding hydrophilicity.40 Figures 1(c) and 1(d) indicate that our CNCs are uniformly dispersed and have a rod-like morphology with a length of around 179±27 nm and an average diameter of 9±2 nm.
The exfoliated CNCs can be facilely fabricated into nanopapers on poly(ether sulfone) microporous membranes by a simple vacuum-filtration method (Scheme 1(b)). These nanopapers are integral, freestanding and transparent after the microporous substrate was dissolved by DMF (Figure S1(a) in SI). The absolute thickness is about 165 ± 5 nm measured by AFM when the CNC loading (mass thickness) reaches to 418 mg m-2 (Figure S1(b) in SI), and it increases with increasing the mass thickness of CNCs (Figure S2 and Figure S3 in SI).
Figure 1. Structure characterization of CNCs. a) FT-IR spectra; b) Conductometric titration curves; c) TEM image; and d) AFM image.

One can also see that the surface pores are quickly decreased by increasing the mass thickness of CNCs on the microporous substrate (Figure S4 inSI) and they are uniformly covered by the CNCs-based nanopapers when the mass thickness is 418 mg m-2.
The wettability behavior was evaluated for the CNCs-based nanopapers by water contact angle (WCA) measurement. It is very interesting that the water droplet quickly spread on the surface or permeate through the nanopapers within 6.5 s (Figure S5 in SI). This demonstrates the superior hydrophilicity of the CNCs-based nanomaterials. At the same time, the underwater oil contact angle (underwater OCA) is around 150°, which is similar to that on a series of typical superhydrophilic m a t e r i a l s i n c l u d i n g n a n o p a r t i c l e s ( c o - d e p o s i t e d polydopamine/ polyethyleneimine (PDA/PEI), biomineralized SiO2 and hydrothermally synthesized ZnO) and nanocoatings (LBL polydiallyldimethylammonium chloride/polystyrene sulfonate ((PDDA/PSS)5, the self-assembly process are
Figure 2. a) Underwater OCA (in left black bars ) and underoil WCA (in right blue bars) of different known superhydrophilic surfaces, including PDA/PEI co-deposition nanoparticles, (PDDA/PSS)5 LBL nanocoating (The LBL selfassembly process are repeated 5 times), hydrothermally synthesized ZnO nanoparticles, biomineralized ZrO2 nanoparticles, biomineralized SiO2 nanoparticles on the PES substrates. The model oil used in the test was isooctane. b) A series of photos taken when an isooctane droplet was approaching or leaving the nanopaper surface in water. c) A series of photos taken when a water droplet was approaching or leaving the nanopaper surface in isooctane.
Figure 3. A series of photos taken when a) CNCs-based nanopaper surface and b) (PDDA/PSS)5 LBL surface, fouled by high viscosity crude oil in air, were immersed into hot water (60 °C). The immersion time is marked in the photographs. GAR-FTIR spectra c) CNCs-based nanopaper surface and d)
(PDDA/PSS)5 LBL surface during different mediums such as air, water and oil. The oil used here was isooctane. repeated 5 times) and biomineralized ZrO2 on the microporous substrate (Figure 2(a) and Figure S6 in SI). However, when the oil droplet is approached to the surface, the CNCs-based nanopapers still keep a high value of OCA (Figure 2(b)). And no oil residual is left on the nanopapers after retracting the oil droplet from the surface. As a contrast, oil adhesion or deformation was observed when oil droplets approach or leave the superhydrophilic surfaces mentioned above (Figure S7 in SI). Additionally, our CNCs-based nanopapers show excellent underwater oil-repellency property with all underwater OCAs higher than 150° for both light oil and heavy oil with different surface tensions (i.e., petrol, dichloroethane, petroleum ether, soybean oil, toluene, isooctane and crude oil) (Figure S8 in SI). Actually, in the practical applications, the superhydrophilic surfaces tend to be easily contaminated by oil, and thus the water binding affinity of these contaminated surfaces are crucial to clean up oil fouling. Therefore, underoil water cantact angle (underoil WCA) were measured to characterize the water binding ability of the oil-surrounded surfaces. Figure 2(a) shows that the CNCs-based nanopapers exhibit similar water-wetting behavior as that in the air, and the water droplet can still spread on the oil-surrounded surfaces of CNCs-based nanopapers instantly (Figure 2(c)). The underoil WAC is even hardly dectectable (~0o). Differently, the other surfaces with similar superhydrophilic property appear underoil WCA higher than 60. All the results demonstrate that our CNCs nanomaterials possess much better water binding ability than that of aforementioned superhydrophilic materials.

sections.heading: ARTICLE Journal Name
sections.text:
4 | J. Name., 2012, 00, 1-3 This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
This is attributed to the special chemical structures and tremendous sulfuric acid ester groups in CNCs, which can induce strong long-range “hydro-philic“ attraction to realize water binding and oil diplacement ability via ion-dipole or dipole-dipole interactions.26-27
In general, crude oils have higher viscosity and adhesive property than the model oils used in the above-mentioned experiments, which brings a great challenge for the separation of oil/water mixtures.41 Therefore, the de-wetting behavior was studied in detail for the CNCs-based nanopapers by fouling the surfaces with crude oil in the air without prehydration and then immersing them into water at 60°C. It can be seen that the crude oil film on the CNCs-based nanopapers firstly deform and turn into oil droplets, then the oil droplets detach from the nanopaper surfaces within 20 s (Figure 3(a) and Movie S1 in SI). We suggest that, during the detachment process, the strong hydratability of CNCs promotes the adsorption of a water layer on the nanopaper surface, which further facilitates the detachment of oil adsorbed. To clearly elucidate this mechanism, we chose a surface with abundant sulfonate groups (PDDA/PSS via LBL process) to carry out the similar experiment (Figure 3(b) and Movie S2 in SI). It can be seen that the crude oil film still adheres to the (PDDA/PSS)5 modified polyethersulfone membrane surface stably and remains unchanged even after 120 s in the hot water. The difference of self-cleaning ability is due to that the sulfuric acid ester groups in CNCs are closely and densely bonded on the nanocrystal surface compared with those on the flexible chains of PSS, which ensures that the original orientation of the hydrophilic groups resists to transform even when exposed the surfaces to oil or air. The grazing-angle-reflectance Fourier transform infrared (GAR-FTIR) spectra were used to characterize the orientation of the hydrophilic groups in different mediums (Figure 3(c)).34,42-43 For CNCs, the integration ratio of S=O stretching vibration peaks measured in water, air, and oil is 1:0.91:0.89 (water: air: oil). It shows that the intensity of S=O has a negligible reduction compared to that of (PDDA/PSS)5 surface (water: air: oil = 1:0.5:0.2) when the surroundings are changed to air and oil, respectively. (Figure 3(d)). The flexible hydrophilic groups prefer to orient inward spontaneously to minimize the overall surface energy while they are exposed to non-polar media. Instead, the rigid surfaces of CNCs will inhibit the inward orientation of the hydrophilic groups. Therefore, this isotropic configuration of sulfuric acid ester groups provides strong and stable hydratability for the CNCs-based nanomaterials even in oil medium. In addition, the underwater crude oil adhesion force was measured to quantitatively evaluate the hydratability of various surfaces mentioned above (Figure S9 in SI). When a crude oil droplet was forced to sufficiently contact the CNCsbased nanopaper surface, the monitored adhesive force is nearly 0 µN during the leaving process (Figure S10 in SI), showing excellent anti-crude oil adhesion property. In contrast, the adhesive force is above 15 µN for all the other hydrophilic surfaces, and it follows an order of ZnO nanoparticles ˂ (PDDA/PSS)5 LBL nanocoating ˂ SiO2 nanoparticles ˂ ZrO2
Figure 4. Anti-crude oil-adhesion and self-cleaning property of CNCs nanocoatings on various substrates. a) Digital photo of the CNCs-coated surfaces and b) images for the underwater crude oil contact angle of various CNCs-coated substrates. Photographs that show the self-cleaning property of the CNCs-coated Cu foils fouled by heavy crude oil in air: c) with pre-hydration, and d) without pre-hydration. Photographs in the blue frame in c) display the Cu foils without CNCs nanocoating.
nanocoating ˂ PDA/PEI co-deposition nanoparticles, which are much higher than that of CNCs. Interestingly, this result is almost in aggreement with that of the underoil WCA, demonstrating the CNCs-based nanomaterials with low underoil WCA show superior anti-crude oil adhesion property. Our CNCs can also be coated on various substrates, including copper foils, copper meshes, polycarbonate sheets, poly(ether sulfone) microfiltration membranes, glass plates, AAO membranes, and silica wafers via LBL assembly method with PDDA (Scheme 1(c) and Figure 4(a)). These coatings can be confirmed by AFM and SEM images (Figure S11 and Figure S12 in SI). Figure 4(b) shows that the underwater crude oil contact angle is around 155° for all the CNCs-coated substrates, displaying their good underwater superoleophobic property.
Figure 4(c-d) also demonstrates that, when the CNCs-coated materials with pre-hydration and without pre-hydration state are fouled by crude oil in the air, the crude oil contamination can detach from the surface immediately (Movie S3-4 in SI) and show excellent self-cleaning property once these materials are immersed into aqueous environment. Instead, the origin material surfaces are still contamined by the crude oil, and the oil are still adhesived on the surface even after vigorous shaking. All these results indicate the feasibility and universality of CNCs coatings as well as excellent crude oilrepellent property.
The effects of pH and salt on the hydratability of CNCs nanomaterials were further assessed in detail. For pH stability, the CNCs-based nanopapers were firstly kept in water solutions with different pH values ranging from 3 to 12 for 7 days. Then their underwater OCAs and underwater crude oil adhesive forces were measured. Figure 5(a) exhibits

Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
that the CNCs-based nanopapers keep underwater OCA above 150°, and the underwater crude oil adhesive forces are around 0 μN while its surroundings are neutral or alkaline water solution. The ultralow underwater crude oil adhesive force and suprior underwater superoleophobic property can still maintain at acidic environment until pH < 4. Though the underwater OCA is about 150° without obvious decline when the pH is lower than 4, the crude oil adhesive force is increased to 2.5±0.2 μN at pH = 4. This is caused by the protonation and deprotonation processes of the sulfuric acid ester groups in CNCs at different conditions. When the pH is higher than 4, the CNCs tend to be completely deprotonated. In general, the deprotonated CNCs present stronger negatively charged and higher hydration capability than protonated ones. The negatively charged surfaces can repel oil contamination due to the electrostatic repulsion effect. The strong hydration capability can form a robustly physical barrier to prevent the adhesion of crude oil.21,42 The CNCsbased nanopapers were also immersed into 50 mg mL-1 of Na2SO4, CaCl2, KCl, MgCl2, Na2CO3, NaCl and sea water solutions for 7 days, respectively. Figure 5(b) implies that all of the samples exhibit stable underwater superoleophobicity and ultralow oil adhesive property. These results indicate that the CNCs have spuerior and robust hydratability, which possesses great potential for crude oil remediation process even in some harsh environments like high salinity, strong alkali and weak acidity surroundings.
Surprised by their superior hydration capability and anti-oil adhesion property, we further compare them with other state-ofthe-art anti-oil materials reported in literatures (Table 1). The CNCsbased nanomaterials show excellent oil-repellent property for crude oil even without pre-hydration while most of the other materials should be wetted by water before use, which greatly hinder their application in practical crude oil remediation. In addition, it can be found that the separation of crude oil/water emulsions, especially the surfactant-stabilized oil-in-water emulsions, is hardly achieved by these materials (Table 1). Thus, the CNCs-based nanopapers were prepared by simple vacuum-filtration for the separation of
Figure 6. Separation performance of the CNCs-based nanopapers and Cu meshes with CNCs-based nanocoatings for the surfactant-stabilized crude oil-in-water emulsions and the crude oil/water mixtures (1:1 in volume), respectively. Microscopic photographs of surfactant-stabilized crude oil-in-water emulsions a) before and b) after separation by the CNCs-based nanopapers. c) Water permeation flux and oil content in filtrate over 12 cycles by the CNCs-based nanopapers. d) SEM of the Cu meshes with CNCs-based nanocoatings. e) Water permeation flux and oil content in filtrate over 12 cycles by the Cu meshes with the CNCs-based nanocoating.
crude oil-in-water emulsions due to the small pore size in our case. It can be seen that the water permeation flux declines non-linearly from 16000±2300 L m-2 h-1 bar-1 to 7300±640 L m-2 h-1 bar-1 while the thickness of the CNCs-based nanopapers increases from 118 nm to 340 nm (Figure S13 in SI). This is because the water permeation flux is not only depending on the thickness but also on the pore size of the nanopapers. We analyzed the effective pore size of the CNCsbased nanopapers with a thickness of 165 nm by filtrating gold nanoparticles (15 nm) and nanoemulsions ranging from 10 nm to 100 nm. After filtration, the filtrate is transparent without Tyndall effect and the DLS curve also confirms the disappearance of oil droplets (Figure S14 and Figure S15 in SI). The gold nanoparticles can also be fully blocked by the nanopapers (Figure S16 in SI). Although, chemical adsorption exists between gold nanoparticles and nanopapers via the electrostatic force since they exhibit opposite charges. The surface charges of nanopapers are with certain amount and this adsorption would easily reach to a saturation state. After the adsorption goes beyond the saturation point, the electrostatic effect would have little influence on the blockage of nanoparticles44,45. Therefore, it is reasonable to conclude that the gold nanoparticles are mainly blocked by the “size sieving effect” in our case. These results indicate that the effective pore size of the CNCs-based nanopapers is below 10 nm and it is available for separating crude oil from those surfactantstabilized crude oil-in-water emulsions in nanoscale. Separation of crude oil-in-water emulsions was carried out on a glass separation instrument equipped with the CNCs-based nanopapers and the result is shown in Figure 6. The crude oil is totally rejected and recovered by the nanopapers. No crude oil droplets can be observed in the microscopic photographs after one-cycle separation, indicating almost all crude oil droplets are removed from the emulsions. In addition, these nanopapers show extremely high water permeation flux as 3700 L·m2·h·bar-1 while the oil content in the filtrates after one round separation is around 40 ppm, which is

~ 3700 (1 bar) ~ 0 [a] This work
[a] Measursed by a high-sensitivity micro-electro-mechanical balance system in this work. [b] Obtained from the corresponding article. Abbreviation:
PDA/PEI, polydopamine/polyethyleneimine; PMPC, poly(2-methacryl-oyloxylethyl phosphorylcholine); CNFs, cellulose nanofibrils; CNCs, cellulose nano-
crystals; PP, polypropylene; PVDF, polyvinylidene fluoride; PES, poly(ether sulfone); AMOE, aqueous model oil emulsion; ACOM, aqueous crude oil
mixture; ACOE, aqueous crude oil emulsion; AMOM, aqueous model oil mixture; W/O E, water-in-oil emulsion; n.m., not measured. below the discharge standards of the Environmental Protection Agency of U.S. for offshore oil and gas activities and the discharge standard of the Ministry of Environmental Protection of China. We further evaluated its long-term stability by recording the water permeation flux and the oil content in the filtrate water during 12 cycles. After each-cycle,
the nanopapers were immersed into water to clean off the residual crude oil on the surfaces. The permeation flux remains unchanged all the time while the oil content is always around 40 ppm in each-cycle, indicating their excellent anti-oil property and high long-term operation stability.The nanopore-size CNCs nanopapers could not offer favorable water flux if they are practically applied for treating the crude oil/water mixtures during oil spill accidents. Therefore, copper meshes with pore size of 25 µm coated with the CNCs-based nanocoatings were used for this purpose. It can be seen that
there is no obvious decline for the pore size after assembling the PDDA/CNCs nanocoatings (Figure 6(d)). The PDDA/CNCscoated meshes were put on a home-made apparatus (Figure S17 in SI) and the separation was driven only by gravity without extra pressure input. In a typical cycle, clean water passes through the meshes whereas crude oil is rejected.
Figure 6(e) shows that the permeation flux of the PDDA/CNCscoated Cu meshes is much higher than that of the CNCs-based nanopapers while the oil content in the filtrate still keeps very low of 40 ppm. Besides, there is no decline in performance of the PDDA/CNCs-coated meshes even after 12 cycles, implying their excellent long-term stability.

sections.heading: 3. Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, we report a facile, green and universal strategy to utilize natural and renewable building blocks, CNCs, as the

sections.heading: Journal Name ARTICLE
sections.text:
This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx J. Name., 2013, 00, 1-3 | 7
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
crude oil repellent nanomaterials. The CNCs are constructed on different substrate surfaces via simple vacuum-filtration and LBL assembly protocols. The CNCs-coated surfaces show similar underwater OCA and much lower underoil WCA compared with other hydrophilic surfaces. The special chemical structure of CNCs bestows the modified surfaces with excellent self-cleaning property whether the surfaces are fouled in pre-hydration or dry states. The CNCs-based nanopapers can effectively separate crude oil-in-water emulsions, which have been rarely reported. The meshes with CNCs-based nanocoatings show ultrahigh efficiency in separating crude oil from crude oil/water mixtures and no fluxloss appears during a long-term operation. An important issue is that our CNCs-based nanomateriala can still remain ultralow crude oil adhesive property in wide pH range and high salinity environments. Last but not least, these simple and green materials are even suitable for real crude oil/water in practical oil-spill cleanup.

sections.heading: 4.1 Materials
sections.text:
MCC was purchased from Shanghai Chineway Pharma. Tech. Co. Ltd (China). Various substrates including copper foils, copper meshs, polycarbonate sheets, glass plates and silicon wafers were commercially available from markets. Aluminium anodic oxidation (AAO) membranes were obtained from Whatman International Ltd. Poly(ether sulfone) microporous membrane (average pore size: 0.22 mm) was procured from Haining Xindongfang Technology Co. Ltd (China). The heavy and light crude oils were kindly provided by PetroChina Co. Ltd (China). Polyethyleneimine (PEI, Mw = 600 Da), tris(hydroxylmethyl) aminomethane (Tris-HCl), tetramethyl orthosilicate (TMOS) and polydiallyldimethylammonium chloride (PDDA, Mw = 250 000 Da) were obtained from Aladdin Co., Ltd (China). Dopamine hydrochloride (DA) was procured from SigmaAldrich (USA). Other chemicals, including various inorganic salts and organic solvents, were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. All the reagents were used without further purification. The water used in all experiments was deionized and ultrafiltered to 18.2 MΩ·cm with an ELGA 136 LabWater system (France). 4.2 Synthesis of the Cellulose Nanocrystals Dispersion CNCs were exfoliated from MCC by sulfuric acid hydrolysis according to a previously reported method.35,49 Briefly, MCC (10 g) was added to 100 mL of 64 wt% sulfuric acid solution. The hydrolysis process was kept at 45 °C for 4 h under vigorous stirring. Then the product was diluted to 10% of the original concentration to stop the hydrolysis reaction. After that, the dispersion was centrifuged, washed with ultrapure water, and recentrifuged. Finally, the dispersion was dialyzed in ultrapure water to remove residual H2SO4 until the pH of water was neutral. The resulting dispersion was further ultrasonically dispersed in ultrapure water before use. 4.3 Preparation of CNCs-based Nanopapers CNCs nanopapers were prepared by vacuum filtration of the CNCs dispersion on poly(ether sulfone) membrane with an average pore size of 0.22 µm. The thickness of the CNCs-based nanopapers was tuned by changing the amount of the CNCs dispersion used in the filtration process. The prepared nanopapers were then dried overnight. The free-standing CNCs-based nanopapers were obtained by dissolving the poly(ether sulfone) substrate in DMF. 4.4 Fabrication of CNCs-based nanocoatings Various substrates, including copper foils, copper meshs, polycarbonate sheets, glass plates and AAO membranes, were washed by ethanol and water to remove impurity prior to LBL assembly. The silicon wafers were incubated in Piranha solution (1:3 (v/v) mixture of 30% H2O2 and 98% H2SO4) for 4 hours. Then, they were washed by ultrapure water, and dried with N2. In a typical LBL assembly process, the substrates were firstly exposed to a PDDA solution (2 g/L) for 20 min and then washed triple times with ultrapure water for 10 s in each time. Subsequently, the substrates were immersed into CNCs dispersion with a concentration of 0.88 g/L for another 20 min followed by washing with ultrapure water as described above. This process was repeated for 5 times to fabricate PDDA/CNCs nanocoatings on the substrate surfaces. 4.5 Fabrication of nanoparticle of PDA/PEI, SiO2, ZnO and nanocoatings of PDDA/PSS, ZrO2 on poly(ether sulfone) microporous membranes Co-deposited PDA/PEI nanoparticles: DA and PEI with a concentration of 2 mg/mL were dissolved in Tris-buffer solution (200 mM, pH=8.5). Then poly(ether sulfone) membranes were immersed into the deposition solution and shaken at 25 °C for 6 hours. The as-prepared membranes were washed by ultrapure water and dried at room temperature.46,50 LBL PDDA/PSS nanofilms: The poly(ether sulfone) membranes were placed into PDDA solution (2 g/L) for 20 min firstly, and then washed triple times with ultrapure water for 10 s in each time. Secondly, the membranes were immersed into PSS solution (2 g/L) for another 20 min. This process was repeated for 5 times to obtain PDDA/PSS nanocoatings on poly(ether sulfone) membrane.42 Hydrothermally synthesized ZnO nanoparticles: The PDA/PEI modified poly(ether sulfone) membranes were put into ZnCl2 solution (0.0125M) and the pH of this solution was adjusted to 10.35 by dropwise adding ammonia solution (28%). The poly(ether sulfone) membranes were kept in the solution at 90 °C for 5h. Finally, the as-prepared membranes were taken out and washed by ultrapure water.51 Biomineralized ZrO2 nanoparticles: Zirconium sulfate tetrahydrate was dissolved in hydrochlric solution (40 mmol/L) with a concentration of 4 mmol/L. Then, the PDA-PEI modified poly(ether sulfone) membranes were immersed into the solution at 25 °C for 12h.50 Biomineralized SiO2 nanoparticles: 0.15 mL TMOS was added to 10 mL HCl solution (1 mM) under stirring for 15 min, and mixed with 10 mL phosphate buffer solution (0.2 M, pH = 6.0). The PDA/PEI modified poly(ether sulfone) membranes were immersed into the above solution for 4h at room temperature. The membranes were taken out and washed by ultrapure water, then the membranes were dried for further use.47 4.6 Characterization

sections.heading: ARTICLE Journal Name
sections.text:
8 | J. Name., 2012, 00, 1-3 This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, Hitachi, S4800, Japan) was used to observe the surface morphologies of various substrates, CNCs-based nanopapers, and CNCsbased nanocoatings. Transmission electron microscopy (Hitachi 7700, Japan) was applied to characterize the synthesized CNCs. The chemicial structures of CNCs were analyzed by Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (FTIR/ATR, Nicolet 6700, USA) and X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS, PerkinElmer, USA) with Al Kα excitation radiation (1486.6 eV), respectively. The sulfuric acid ester group content of CNCs was measured by conductometric titration method according to the previous work35, 40. Firstly, NaCl (0.025 g) was added into 100 mL CNCs suspension to increase conductivity to a measurable range. NaOH (10 mM) was then titrated in 100 µL intervals with constant stirring, while keep measuring the conductivity of the suspension. First, the conductivity decrease with added NaOH as the protons associated with the sulfate acid ester groups are consumed. Then, the conductivity increase with NaOH added since all the charged groups have been neutralized. The inflection point was calculated by the intersection of the two linear regions. The sulfuric acid ester group content (SE, mmol/m2) was calculated by using the following equation: SE = (VNaOH × CNaOH)/mCNCs × ρCNCs × DCNCs Where VNaOH is the volume of the NaOH required for neutralization and CNaOH is the 10 mM. mCNCs is the mass of the CNCs used in the conductometric titration process. ρCNCs and DCNCs are the density and diameter of the CNCs, respectively. The water contact angle and the underwater oil contact angle were measured by the drop Meter A-200 contact angle system (MAIST Vision Inspection & Measurement Co. Ltd, China). The underwater oil-adhesive force was measured with a highsensitivity micro-electro-mechanical balance system (DataPhysics DCAT11, Germany). The GAS-FITR spectra was measured on a Bruker Vertex 70 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer fitted with a reflectance accessory. The oil content in the filtrate was deyermined on a total organic carbon (TOC) analyzer (GE, USA). 4.6 Crude oil/water separation The crude oil/water emulsions were first prepared by mixing light crude oil with a 0.05 mg/L SDS water solution (1:99 in volume) and then stirring them for 2 hours. The prepared emulsions were separated by CNCs-based nanopapers with a separation area of 11.34 cm2 supported by poly(ether sulfone) microporous substrate. This composite membrane was settled on a vacuum filter apparatus. Then, 200 mL of crude oil/water emulsions were added into the apparatus and the separation process was driven at 0.5 bar. As for the separation of crude oil/water mixture (1:1 in volume), the PDDA/CNCs-coated mesh was fixed between two homemade glass tubes. Then, 500 mL of crude oil/water mixture was poured into the uptube and the separation was achieved driven by gravity. Finally, the filtrate was collected to determine its TOC.

sections.heading: Conflicts of interest
sections.text: There are no conflicts to declare.

sections.heading: Acknowledgement
sections.text: Financial support is acknowledged to the Zhejiang Provincial Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant no. Z15E030002), and the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant no. 21534009). We also thank Prof. Yanlei Yu and Mr. Xin Qing from Fudan University, for their help in underwater adhesive force measurement.
